data.text: Bicycle Touring and Achilles Tendon

I did a spontaneous 110km yesterday. I have very tender Achilles‚Äô tendons (Achilles Tendinitis) this morning. I‚Äôm 41yo and relatively new to cycling. I peddle using flats/platform pedals and sports trainers. Any advice welcome‚Ä¶.
Maybe try flat cycling shoes. The firm base might help the heel/foot from ove stretching

data.author: Peter Lownie

data.text: Bike fit. Normally about a hundred quid, but you can find an LBS able to do a basic fit from about 40. Or you can Google for tips on the basics. It's quite possible that the saddle height is wrong, which strains your ankles. But other than that, 110k if you're relatively new to it is no mean feat. Some soreness is only to be expected. You need to do the fit anyway, with or without external help, but see if the issue persists - it may go away once you get used to it. Longer-term, clipless pedals are a lot more efficient, and despite what laypeople think, safer. If you're into bikepacking, probably SPD - they afford you to walk a bit in the same shoes, i.e., when having to push the bike. You can squeeze pedals and shoes into 100 quid.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: thanks for the reply üëç
data.author: Peter Lownie

data.text: Hi Pavel how are you? Great advice, how are clipless pedals safer? I don‚Äôt wear them on my commute because I feel less safe with them but I‚Äôm open to change
data.author: Robbie Cryer

data.text: It's a lot harder to lose the footing if you're clipped in when you go over a bump or a pothole, especially compared to smooth flat pedals and smooth-soled shoes. And having a foot slipping off can unsaddle you and/or result in a significant kick up the groin with the saddle. People often feel apprehensive about not being able to clip out when needed, but it's all a matter of habit. Just get into the habit of twisting the foot first, not yanking it, and it'll become second nature. I also clip one foot out a few seconds in advance if I know I'll need to stop, e.g., at traffic lights. There's also the fact that if you do end up tumbling over, it's safer to do it still attached to the bike: it'll take some of the brunt. Yes, a lot of people would sustain a personal injury rather than have their bike scratched, but that's just naive. As any outdoor instructor worth their salt would put it, you protect the person first, and then the kit. But as a whole, in 20+ years of riding on clipless, I've never - literally not once - have tumbled over because of being clipped in. For other reasons, yes, a few times, but not this.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Cheers Pavel, that‚Äôs really convinced me to use clipless on my commute!
data.author: Robbie Cryer

data.text: I get pain in my right Achilles. I‚Äôd say flats and normal trainers is a good thing if they have hard soles. I‚Äôd also say 110km is quite a distance if you are not used to it, deffo build up to it to avoid injury! Try a foot roller and also a foam roller or lacross ball on your calves. Achilles is hard to stretch / could also be bursitis. It can stem as far up as your ITB so foam roll the fuck out of everything including hips. All connected!

data.author: Peter Lownie

data.text: Could be anything from pedalling technique to pedal size, but I would bet on it being your use of non-cyling shoes (flexible sole). Regardless, it's important for you to do Achilles stretches before your next few rides. Achilles tendinitis can easily become a chronic problem (been there myself; overtraining for long jump many years ago).
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: thank you
data.author: Peter Lownie

data.text: I think going from 25km max (4times a month) to 110km might have contributed to the problem too
data.author: Peter Lownie

data.text: absolutely; over-training will expose limitations in your body or equipment.
data.author: David Rowe

data.author: Marcus Hearle

data.text: There are plenty of touring spd shoes that can be used as flats with a cover plate, then if you want to try spd you already have the shoe. I like Giro shoes but that‚Äôs personal choice.
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: I suggest a quick look at your saddle height and foot position through the circle. Sore achilles can easily be the result of over extending (think high saddle/toes constantly pointed). I'm a firm non believer in cycle specific shoes to "fix" a problem. You don't mention how much longer that is than your normal ride distance, but if it's significantly longer then don't rule out that it might simply be a matter of too much too soon (though I doubt it, more likely that the extra distance highlights a problem that your body can deal with at lower distance).
data.author: Sigrid Identitee

data.text: Seat too high most likely explanation as mentioned above. Overextending yourself can cause all sorts of troubles. As others have said you maybe pushed yourself a wee bit further than your body was comfortable with. You really dont need expensive bike shoes, anything with a firm sole will do the job. I ride in walking boots when i`m doing rough trail rides. Makes the hike a bike so much easier if you have footwear designed for walking on rough ground. That is where bike shoes fall down. No use for walking over rocky ground or up mountains.
data.author: Jim McNeil

data.text: thank you
data.author: Peter Lownie

data.text: For the first time ever I had problems with my achilles tendons after doing a 600km (hilly Wales) recently. Never done more than 400km in the past and all in the flat lands of East Anglia . Rested for a few days, lowered the saddle 1cm and seem to be OK now. So I reckon too much in one go without building up gradually and getting your body dialled into more challenging work. Also have a proper stretch before heading out
data.author: Andrew Hoppit

data.text: are you using clip-in pedals?

data.text: oh sorry, you did say, I guess you just over did it, stretch well first and ride shorter distances at first is my advice
data.author: Roland Bai

data.text: Saddle height, foot position. Using flats is an advantage as you can move your feet around a bit. It might be just the fact you've overdone it a bit if you are fairly new to cycling and extending distances. The next 100k might be a bit more comfortable as your body gets used to it.
